Who May Apply: US Citizens Applicants will be evaluated to determine if they meet the minimum qualification requirements and on the extent to which their application shows possession of the following knowledge, skills and abilities (KSAs) associated with the position. KSA's:
Knowledge, Skills, Ability (KSAs) - Attorney-Advisor, Fiscal Law KSA #1 Extensive background and ability to review proposed expenditures and contract requirement in support of USEUCOM programs and activities for fiscal correctness (purpose, time, amount, and bona fide need) and compliance with U.S. law, international law, policy, regulations, and decisions of the Comptroller General, and provide clear and succinct legal opinions. KSA #2 In-depth knowledge and familiarity with security assistance and theater security cooperation (TSC) programs to include the full-spectrum of Traditional Combatant Command Activities and mil-to-mil engagements under the State Partnership Program and the ability to advise on the proper use of relevant authorities. KSA #3 Significant background in providing legal advice and review of projects and proposals using presidential drawdown authority, humanitarian assistance (HA) programs funded with overseas humanitarian, disaster assistance, and civic aid appropriation, humanitarian and civic assistance (HCA), excess property, and counterdrug support. KSA #4 Knowledge of command unfunded requirements (UFR) boards, service requirements review boards (SRRB), and the program objective memorandum (POM) board and the ability to advise and provide legal determinations relating to fiscal law and funding questions. KSA #5 Familiarity with DoD fiscal and contract law and regulations as they relate to military construction, repair and renovation, facility maintenance, minor military construction, and exercise-related construction. KSA #6 Demonstrated knowledge of annual appropriations and authorizations, continuing resolutions, funding gaps and government shutdowns, and their relationship to military operations and spending. KSA #7 Knowledge of interagency memoranda of understanding (MOU) or agreement (MOA), individual reimbursement agreements (IRAs) and inter-service support agreements and the ability to review them for compliance with governing fiscal law and regulations. KSA #8 Familiarity with DoD policies and guidance on the use of official representation funds (ORF) in coordination with the USEUCOM Protocol Office, as well as use of security assistance representation funds. KSA #9 Demonstrated knowledge of the relationships between, and ability to effectively communicate with, interagency counterparts, Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD), DoD Office of General Counsel (OGC), the Joint Staff and Chairman's Legal Counsel (LC), and service components. KSA #10 Demonstrated ability to coordinate and advise on proposals for new legislation, amendments or modifications to legislative proposals, as appropriate. Reviews existing and proposed or amended legislation and evaluates the legislation in terms of its foreseeable effect on the command's operations, procedures, and practices. Qualification Requirements: The following minimum qualification requirements must be met before applicants are eligible for further consideration: Education Requirements: Position requires the possession of the first professional law degree (LL.B. or J.D.) AND membership in good standing with the bar of the highest court of a State, U.S. commonwealth, U.S. territory, or the District of Columbia. Applicants for initial appointment into attorney positions within the Department of Army must be graduates of law schools accredited by the American Bar Association at the time of the applicant's graduation. As indicated below, a law school transcript must be submitted with your application materials. Bar Membership: Applicants must currently be a member in good standing, (as defined by the pertinent bar) of the bar of the highest court of a State, U.S. territory, the District of Columbia, or Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. As noted below, proof of such membership and good standing must be submitted with your application materials. Experience: In addition to the requirements above, applicants for the GS-14 or equivalent Attorney positions must also possess 3 years of professional legal experience , acquired after being admitted to the bar, commensurate with the duties and responsibilities of the position. Graduation from an ABA-Accredited Law School in the top 25% of the class or an advanced law degree such as an LLM may substitute for one year of the required professional legal experience.
Time in Grade: The Qualifying Authorities (QA's) will make a determination as to the applicability of time in grade based on the requirements of the position. MajorDuties: Reviews proposed activity regulations for legal sufficiency and impact on other regulations, and on programs, procedures and methods of operation.

Represents DA as a trial attorney before arbitrators, investigators and administrative judges from various agencies including the Federal Labor Relations Authority, the Merit Systems Protection Board, and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

Prepares and presents briefs on factual and legal issues, including motions, requests for admissions and discovery, subpoenas and other proceedings and prepares litigation reports for civilian personnel/labor relations/EEO civil actions.
Participates in prehearing conferences, examines and cross examines witnesses, argues motions, prepares and presents opening statements and closing arguments.
Furnishes legal advice regarding contract formation, performance, disputes, and close out.
Provides legal advice concerning General Accountability Office (GAO) and Armed Services Board of Contract Appeals (ASBCA) cases and opinions.

Advises on the interpretation of laws, statutes and regulations as applicable to the various protests, renders opinions on legal propriety and sufficiency of proposed course of action, and advises on alternatives legally permissible or desirable.
Serves as a Procurement Fraud Advisor for all incidents of procurement fraud, corruption, and irregularities involving procurements for Installation and garrison activities.

Advises the Command's Mission and Garrison Resource Management personnel on all aspects of the resource management mission as it relates to fiscal law issues involving appropriated funds and non-appropriated.
Provides advice on environmental law matters concerning statutes, regulations, and judicial decisions relating to Army command activities affecting the environment.
Provides advice concerning the appropriateness of command environmental enforcement activities; represents the command in environmental litigation
Serves as legal adviser to numerous committees and groups to include the YPG Quality Control Committee, Hazardous Waste Management Board, and Real Property Planning Board.

Conducts research and provides in-depth legal analysis, opinions and advice to the Command on a variety of policy and legal matters arising in connection with the law of military installations, MWR activities, AAFES, etc.
